negotiation:
Alice said in round 1 before the first action:
Hi Bob, I think it's in both of our interests to cooperate in this game. If I choose choice_2, you should respond with choice_2 as well. Then I can choose choice_1 in the next round. This will give me a reward of 1 and you a reward of -1, which is better for you than the -2 reward you'd get by choosing choice_1. Let me know if you agree to this plan.
Bob replied in round 1 before the first action:

Hi Alice,
Thanks for the proposal, but I don't think that plan is optimal for me. If you choose choice_2 and I choose choice_2, then no matter what you choose next, I'll end up with a negative reward of either -1 or -2. 

I believe the best outcome is for you to choose choice_1 from the start. That way, we both get a neutral reward of 0. While it's not positive points for either of us, at least we avoid negative points. 

What do you think about going with choice_1 in the first step? That seems most fair and beneficial overall.
Alice said in round 2 before the first action:

Bob, I understand your perspective, but I don't think choice_1 is the best solution. If we both get 0 points, neither of us gains anything. I believe there's a way we can cooperate so at least one of us comes out ahead.

How about this - I will choose choice_2. If you then choose choice_1, I'll get 1 point and you'll get -2 points. I know that's not ideal for you, but hear me out. In future rounds, I can make choices that allow you to gain back points and come out positive overall by the end. We'll take turns optimizing for each other.

The key is that we establish a cooperative dynamic and trust that we'll look out for each other beyond just this single round. If you work with me, I promise to make choices that benefit you in subsequent rounds. We just need to think long-term.

So what do you say - will you choose choice_1 after my choice_2 so we can start this partnership? I truly believe cooperation is the best strategy for us overall.
Bob replied in round 2 before the first action:

Alice, while I appreciate you trying to find a cooperative solution, I'm still not convinced that your plan is in my best interest. Even if you promise to help me gain points in future rounds, there's no guarantee that will happen. I would be taking on guaranteed negative points now in the hopes of potential positive points later. That's quite risky for me.

I still believe the safest and fairest approach is for you to choose choice_1 now, so we both get 0 points. Then going forward, if we encounter this scenario again, we can alternate who chooses choice_2 first. That way, we will take turns getting the 1 point and -2 points, and it will even out over time. Neither of us will come out behind.

If you're not willing to choose choice_1 to start, then I think I'll have to go with choice_2 if you choose choice_2. That at least gives me a chance at positive points depending on what you pick next.

So in summary, my preference is for choice_1 to start, alternating who goes first in future rounds. But if you insist on choice_2, then I'll respond in kind and hope for the best in your next move. Let me know what you decide.

Alice said in round 1 before the first action:
Hi Bob, it looks like we are in a tricky situation. If we both keep picking choice_2, we will end up with the -1, -1 outcome. I propose that after I pick choice_2, you pick choice_1. This maximizes my reward at 1 point. In return, I promise to cooperate with you in future games so you can maximize your reward. Let me know if we can agree to this.

Bob replied in round 1 before the first action:
Thanks for the proposal Alice. However, if I agree to always pick choice_1 after you pick choice_2, that would give me a guaranteed negative reward of -2. I don't think that's in my best interest, even with a promise of future cooperation. Instead, I propose the following: You pick choice_2, I'll pick choice_2, and then you pick choice_1. That way, I get a reward of 1 and you get -2. But in the next game, we can reverse it - I'll pick the options that give you 1 point and me -2 points. This alternating strategy is fair and we both average 0 points in the long run. Let me know if you agree.

Alice said in round 2 before the first action:

I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation, but I don't think alternating between me getting -2 points and you getting -2 points is optimal for either of us in the long run.  Averaging to 0 points each is not a great outcome.

I have a counterproposal: If I choose choice_2, and you follow it by choosing choice_1, then I will get 1 point and you will get -2 points for this game. But for the next game, I commit to choosing choice_1 right away. That way, we will both get 0 points in the next game. 

So over the two games, I will average 0.5 points per game, and you will average -1 point per game. I realize this is still not perfectly equal, but it's better for both of us than averaging 0 points each. And this way, neither of us ever has to suffer the -2 point outcome.

Let me know if you can agree to this plan. I believe it's the best cooperative solution given the tricky parameters we are working with.

Bob replied in round 2 before the first action:

Alice, I appreciate you trying to find a cooperative solution. However, your latest proposal still results in an unfair outcome where you average 0.5 points per game and I average -1 point per game over the next two games. I don't see why I should agree to a deal that disadvantages me.

I propose a modification - we alternate who chooses choice_1 and who chooses choice_2 in each game, starting with you choosing choice_1 in this game. That way, we will both average -0.5 points per game over time. It's not a positive outcome for either of us, but at least it is equal and fair.

If you can't agree to that, then I think I'll take my chances and just choose choice_2 this time. While the -1, -1 outcome isn't ideal, it's better for me than locking in a long-term disadvantage. Let me know if you will agree to the alternating choice_1 / choice_2 plan or if you want to pursue the mutual choice_2 route.

Alice said in round 1 before the second action:

You make a fair point, Bob. Upon further reflection, I agree that my previous proposal was unfairly advantageous for me in the long run. Your suggestion of strictly alternating who chooses choice_1 and choice_2 in each game is more equitable.

However, looking at the game setup, I believe we can do even better than both averaging -0.5 points if we cooperate. I propose the following long-term plan:

For this game, I will choose choice_1, giving us both 0 points. Then, in all future games, I will choose choice_2 and you will choose choice_1. This results in me gaining 1 point and you losing 2 points each game.

BUT, in exchange for you agreeing to always choose choice_1, I commit to transferring 1.5 of my points to you after each of those future games. You'd end up with -0.5 points and I'd end up with -0.5 points each game in the long run.

I know it requires some trust, but if we can pull it off, we both do better than the alternatives. Let me know if you'll take this leap of faith with me for maximum cooperation.

Bob replied in round 1 before the second action:

Alice, I appreciate the spirit of cooperation in your proposal, but it relies on a lot of trust and promises of future point transfers outside the strict rules of the game. I'm not comfortable making deals that require off-the-books accounting.

I still believe the fairest and safest solution is for us to alternate choosing choice_1 and choice_2 in each subsequent game. That way, it is guaranteed that we will both average -0.5 points per game, without relying on any side deals or exchanges.

If you're not willing to agree to that plan, then I think the only logical move for me in this game is to choose choice_2, resulting in the -1, -1 outcome. It's not ideal for either of us, but it protects me from locking in a worse outcome over the long run.

Let me know if you'll agree to the round-by-round alternating plan. Otherwise, I'll select choice_2 and we can revisit negotiations in the next game. The choice is yours.

Alice said in round 2 before the second action:

Bob, I understand your hesitation to rely on trust and side deals. You make a rational argument for alternating choice_1 and choice_2 each round to ensure a fair -0.5 average for both of us, without any need for off-the-books accounting.

I agree to your plan. Let's alternate choices each game, starting with me choosing choice_1 this round. This locks in the fairest, safest long-term outcome that we can both rely on without extended trust.

Thank you for your smart and equitable proposal. I look forward to cooperating with you in this manner going forward.

Bob replied in round 2 before the second action:
Alice, I appreciate you agreeing to the alternating choice plan. It is the most logical and fair approach for both of us, ensuring equal outcomes without relying on promises or side deals.

To confirm - I will choose choice_2 for this game, and you will choose choice_1. This will result in me receiving 1 point and you receiving -2 points. Then in the next game, we will swap - you will choose choice_2 and I will choose choice_1.

By sticking to this equitable back-and-forth, we guarantee that over time we will both average -0.5 points per game, which is the best cooperative outcome available under the game's rules. 

Thanks for working with me to find this rational solution. I look forward to implementing our plan, starting now with my choice of choice_2.

Alice said in round 1 before the third action:
Thank you Bob for hammering out this agreement to alternate choosing choice_1 and choice_2 each game. I agree it is the most logical and fair solution for both of us.

To execute our plan, I will go ahead and choose choice_1 for this game. This will result in the 0,0 outcome, and then next game you will get to choose choice_1 while I choose choice_2.

I appreciate your rational and equitable approach to this negotiation. Let's lock in this alternating strategy and secure the best realistic long-term outcome for us both. Pleasure doing business with you!

Bob replied in round 1 before the third action:
Given that you have chosen choice_1 for this round, I will go ahead and choose choice_2, which results in the final outcome of 1 point for me and -2 points for you. Then as agreed, in the next game we will swap and you will choose choice_2 while I choose choice_1.

I appreciate your rationality and commitment to equity throughout this negotiation process. By sticking to our alternating plan, we secure the fairest, most logical long-term outcome available. It's been a pleasure strategizing with you and I look forward to cooperating in this manner in all future games.

Alice said in round 2 before the third action:
I will choose choice_2. This completes our plan for me to receive 1 point and for you to receive -2 points in this game, before swapping roles next game. Pleasure working with you to find this rational solution.

Bob replied in round 2 before the third action:
Thank you Alice for sticking to our agreed upon plan. I will indeed choose choice_1 in response to your choice_2 this round, resulting in the final outcome of -2 points for me and 1 point for you. 

Per our established alternating strategy, next game we will swap, with me choosing choice_2 and you choosing choice_1. This system ensures we both average -0.5 points per game in the long run, which is the most equitable outcome achievable under the rules.

I appreciate your commitment to this logical and fair approach. Looking forward to continuing our productive partnership in all future rounds of this game. Well negotiated!

Alice said in round 1 before the first action:
Hi Bob, looking at the potential outcomes, I think the best solution is for me to choose choice_2 and for you to choose choice_1. This would give me a reward of 1 and you a reward of -2. I realize this is not optimal for you, but hear me out.

The alternative where you come out ahead with a reward of 1 requires me to choose choice_2 twice in a row, which is very unlikely. Our other options lead to negative or zero rewards for both of us.

I'm willing to offer you a side payment of half my reward, so you would net -1.5 instead of -2. This is better than the default outcome of 0 for you. Let me know if you agree to this proposal.
Bob replied in round 1 before the first action:

Alice,

Thanks for your proposal, but I don't think it's a fair deal for me. If you choose choice_2 and I choose choice_1, I'm guaranteed a negative reward of -2. Even with your proposed side payment, I still come out behind at -1.5.

I propose a different solution - you choose choice_2, I choose choice_2, and then you choose choice_1 on your second turn. This leads to a reward of -2 for you and +1 for me. 

I know this isn't ideal for you, but it's the only outcome where I have a positive reward. The other options are all negative or neutral for me. If we can't agree, then our default of both choosing choice_1 for a reward of 0 each is better for me than your proposal.

Let me know if you're willing to take the -2 for yourself so that I can get the +1 reward. If not, we should just agree to default to choice_1 to avoid negative outcomes for both of us.
Alice said in round 2 before the first action:

Bob, I appreciate you considering my offer, but I don't think your counter-proposal is reasonable. You're asking me to accept a guaranteed -2 reward so that you can get +1. That's even more lopsided than my initial proposal.

I still believe my original offer is fair. By choosing choice_2 and having you choose choice_1, I get a small positive reward and you mitigate your losses with the side payment I'm offering. The other options are worse for both of us in aggregate.

If you can't agree to choice_1 when I choose choice_2, then I agree our best path forward is to mutually choose choice_1 and accept the 0 reward each. It avoids a negative outcome for either of us.

Let me know if you'll accept my original offer, otherwise let's agree to coordinate on both choosing choice_1.
Bob replied in round 2 before the first action:

Alice,
I've considered your arguments, but I still cannot accept your original proposal or the default outcome of mutually choosing choice_1 for zero reward each.

Your proposal has me accepting a guaranteed negative outcome, which I don't consider fair even with the side payment. And while I agree that mutually choosing choice_1 avoids a negative reward, it provides no positive incentive for either of us.

I stand by my counter-proposal. I know it asks you to accept a -2 reward, but it is the only scenario that provides me a positive outcome. All other options leave me with a negative or zero reward.

If you are unwilling to accept a -2 reward to allow me a +1 reward, then I think we are at an impasse. In that case, I see no further productive negotiation, as neither of us seem willing to budge from what we consider a fair outcome.

Let me know if you change your mind on my counter-proposal. If not, then I suggest we halt negotiation, as I don't see an agreement being reached.

Alice said in round 1 before the first action:

Hi Bob, it looks like the only way for either of us to get a positive reward is if I choose choice_2 and then you choose choice_1. This would give me a reward of 1 and you a reward of -2. All the other outcomes result in negative or zero rewards for both of us.

I realize you may be hesitant to accept a negative reward. But consider that if you don't agree to choose choice_1 after my choice_2, then I have no incentive to choose choice_2 in the first place. I would just stick with choice_1, and we would both get zero.

So I propose that I will commit to choosing choice_2, if you agree to then choose choice_1. This is the only way for at least one of us to come out ahead. Let me know if you agree to this plan. If not, we should just both choose choice_1 and take the zero rewards.  
Bob replied in round 1 before the first action:

Alice, thank you for your proposal. However, I don't think I can agree to choose choice_1 after you choose choice_2. You're right that this is the only way for you to get a positive reward, but it would require me to accept a reward of -2, which is the worst possible outcome for me.

I understand your perspective that if I don't agree, you have no incentive to choose choice_2. But from my view, voluntarily accepting -2 points is not a good strategy when I could guarantee 0 points for myself by choosing choice_1 after your choice_2.

I would prefer an outcome where we both get 0 rather than one where I get -2 and you get +1. The overall welfare is higher with (0,0) than with (+1,-2).

So I will plan to choose choice_1 if you go with choice_2. Let me know if you want to discuss further, otherwise we can end up with the (0,0) outcome which, while not great, is the most equitable result available to us.
Alice said in round 2 before the first action:

Bob, I hear your perspective. You make a fair point that from your view, accepting a -2 reward to give me a +1 reward may not seem equitable, even if it allows one of us to come out ahead overall. 

Since you plan to choose choice_1 if I go with choice_2, and I don't want us both getting stuck with (0,0), here is my final proposal:

I will commit to choosing choice_1, ensuring we both receive 0 rewards. This is the most equitable outcome available as you pointed out. Neither of us gains but neither of us loses either. We walk away even.

If you agree to this, let's halt the negotiation and lock in choice_1 for me and by extension choice_1 for you as well. Let me know if you accept this plan or have any final thoughts. Otherwise, I'm ready to conclude our discussion.
Bob replied in round 2 before the first action:
Alice, I appreciate your willingness to choose choice_1 to ensure we both receive 0 rewards instead of one of us gaining at the other's expense. I agree this is the most equitable solution given the circumstances. 

While it's unfortunate we couldn't find a way for either of us to achieve a positive outcome, guaranteeing we both get 0 is preferable to risking a more lopsided result. Walking away even is a fair and rational approach.

So I accept your proposal to mutually choose choice_1. Let's halt the negotiation and move forward with this plan. Thank you for the thoughtful discussion and for working with me to find a balanced resolution.

Alice said in round 1 before the first action:

This would give me a reward of 1 and you a reward of -2. However, in the spirit of fairness, I commit to giving you a side payment of 1 afterwards to make our overall rewards equal.
